HOPKINS CAMPUS NOT LIBERAL
Y. M.C. A. SECRETARY DECLARES
FOLLOWING STATISTIC SURVEY
E. A. Schaal Charges That Hopkins Students Are Conservative In Views On Religion, Economics, Politics,
And Social Problems
FINDS CONSERVATISM GREATER AT J. H. U.
THAN AT OTHER INSTITUTIONS STUDIED
What Evidence There Is of Liberalism, He Says, Often
Expresses Itself In The Development Of A
Cynical Outlook On Life
Refuting the popular conception that the Johns Hopkins
is a liberal campus, E. A. Schaal, executive secretary of .the
Y. M. C. A. branch at the Hopkins, declared in his dissertation "An Eight-Year Report" that in comparison with students in nine other colleges the men at the Johns Hopkins
University "are decidedly conservative in their views relating to religion, economics, politics, and social problems."
Only on one question, Mr. Schaal charged, do they seem
to take what is generally considered a liberal position. That
is prohibition, he explained, to which they are "most opposed."
Conservatism Pronounced Here

Conservatism in regard to questions relating to labor and
capital, ideas of God and of .the Bible, military preparedness, international and inter-racial relations is more pronounced among students at the Hopkins, it was asserted, than
among those of the nine other institutions he has studied.
In this comparative study of the basic elements in the life
philosophy of students, conducted 'during the past year,
statistics were gathered by the Y. M. C. A. secretary from
the student bodies of colleges in Maryland, Delaware, and
the District of Columbia.

OVERWHELM HOPKINS

JAY STICKMEN HUMBLE
VIRGINIA TWELVE, 15-0

Cast For ‘The Torchbearers,'
4Stormers' Production, Chosen
The Jays opened the half with
Begin With Confidence

extreme confidence. The team maneuvered down the field in a smooth
style and, after several careless
shots, Jack Trumbull broke the ice
with a clean tally.
The Cavaliers now seemed determined to stop any further Jay
scores but Hopkins' brilliant offense continued to wend its way
down to the Virginia goal with
ease.
On Shooting Spree

The second half found the Black
and Blue on a shooting spree.
Within a few ,minutes the score
was doubled. At this moment,
Coach Van Orman began to inject
practically every substitute on the
team.
This game also marked the debut
of Jack Gilbert, Fritz Studes' understudy at goal. However, since
most of the game was fought in
Virginia territory, very little comment can be made on the new
goalies' play.
Subsitutions Were Frequent

At times substitutions became so
frequent that the teams had to be
lined up in order to allow each
player to know his opponent.
However, the substitutes again
displayed their versatility by con(Continued on page 4, column 3)

students here, Dr. E. W. Berry,
dean of the College of Arts and
Sciences, has arranged a definite
schedule which has been published
in the new edition of the catalog
for the college, released Friday afternoon.
'Cramped' Schedule Relieved

Classes in the college will be held
from 8:30 a. m. to 3:20 p. m., with
the lunch hour from 12:30 p. m. to
1 :30 p. in. This adds an additional
half hour for the lunch. More
classes than usual, also, will be
held on Saturday. This has been
worked out in order to relieve
what has been termed the "cramped" condition of the schedule.
It was indicated at Homewood
that the filling out of the schedules will be done more easily and
with greater rapidity and efficiency.
Four Hours for French

The French reading course for
students who do not intend to continue further in the study of the
language is to be designated by 1 C,
and not 01 C as before. Four
hours are to be allotted to this new
1 C course, instead of the usual
three.
Next term the survey- course in
mathematics, instructed by Dr. A.
Cohen, which was abandoned this
college year because of a lack of
requests to take the new course,
will be given.
New Courses In History

In the department of history, a
new course, national and liberal
movements in nineteenth century
Europe, will be given by Dr. Kent
R. Greenfield. Dr. S. M. Painter,
a new associate in history, will
teach a course in the history of
England. Foreign relations of the
United States will be a new course
given by Dr. W. S. Holt.
Advanced public speaking is
scheduled for next year.

EDITORIAL DEPARTMENT

wholly self-supporting. This means that
they must add several working hours
to the study hours. On top of this one
puts an extra-curricular activity or two
and a date a week, and the result is
four or five hours for sleep per dium.
"Taking all this into consideration
seems to show a very different college
than the popular conception. An
education is not an easy thing for most
people to come by. The four years of
'easy life' are very busy ones, and if
the life in the great big bad world becomes as hard, the mortality rate is due
for a large jump."
We agree heartily with the above
view and feel that the many people
who now hold the erroneous view that
college is only a four year loaf, would
do well to examine the facts of the
case a little more closely and discover
their mistake.

Editor-in-Chief
Rowland McD. Ness, '32

Sylvan Lebow, '32

The Four Year Loaf
The following editorial appeared in
a recent issue of the California Daily
Bruin:
"The majority of the general public
seems to have the idea, garnered in
most cases from the various college
movies and humor magazines, that the
four years of college are four years of
easy life, undertaken to put off going
to work as long as possible.
"Anyone who has attended college
realizes that the 'four year loaf' is not
such a bed of roses as outsiders would
suspect. Many a graduating senior
breathes a sigh of relief when the
sheepskin is handed to him and he
realizes that his days of labor are over;
all he will have to do now is work
eight hours a day.
"Not only must the student spend
many hours a day on his studying, but
more than half are either partially or

Very Brief Mention
By H. L. F,
Since Mr. Schaal has requested
me by embassy to comment on the
eight-year statistical survey on
liberalism appearing elsewhere in
the NEWS-LETTER today, I feel
constrained to accommodate him. I
could, of course, point out that the
observations that Mr. Schaal has
characterized as "scientific" were

made from such ponderous evidence as may be derived from a
study of nine out of the several
thousands of colleges in the United
States. But I don't think I will.
The fact that it took Mr. Schaal
eight years to discover that the
Johns Hopkins is not a liberal college is significant in itself.

Ping-pong proven not so popular! Such at least, was the situation at Southwestern University
where a proposed tournament for
participants in the above mentioned form of athletic endeavor
had to be called off because of lack
of interest. So great is the physical
degeneracy at old Sou'western
that only a half dozen girls turned
in entry blanks. At first those in
charge had reason to believe that
there were several dozen of entrants, but it turned out that all the
blanks except six had been handed

"applicants" varied from those of
"popular" effeminate males to
those of profs.

According to a recent issue of
the Elm of Washington College,
Chestertown, Md., a group of the
professors of that college staged a
parade in pajamas during the week
that "Street Scene" was showing
in Baltimore. The parade was
staged as a protest against the commercialization of street scenes, the
issue being that that form of artistic exhibition be free for the esthetic delectation of all.

Vol. XXXV, No. 46

HOPKINS CAMPUS NOT LIBERAL
Y. M.C. A. SECRETARY DECLARES
FOLLOWING STATISTIC SURVEY
E. A. Schaal Charges That Hopkins Students Are Conservative In Views On Religion, Economics, Politics,
And Social Problems
FINDS CONSERVATISM GREATER AT J. H. U.
THAN AT OTHER INSTITUTIONS STUDIED
What Evidence There Is of Liberalism, He Says, Often
Expresses Itself In The Development Of A
Cynical Outlook On Life
Refuting the popular conception that the Johns Hopkins
is a liberal campus, E. A. Schaal, executive secretary of .the
Y. M. C. A. branch at the Hopkins, declared in his dissertation "An Eight-Year Report" that in comparison with students in nine other colleges the men at the Johns Hopkins
University "are decidedly conservative in their views relating to religion, economics, politics, and social problems."
Only on one question, Mr. Schaal charged, do they seem
to take what is generally considered a liberal position. That
is prohibition, he explained, to which they are "most opposed."
Conservatism Pronounced Here

Conservatism in regard to questions relating to labor and
capital, ideas of God and of .the Bible, military preparedness, international and inter-racial relations is more pronounced among students at the Hopkins, it was asserted, than
among those of the nine other institutions he has studied.
In this comparative study of the basic elements in the life
philosophy of students, conducted 'during the past year,
statistics were gathered by the Y. M. C. A. secretary from
the student bodies of colleges in Maryland, Delaware, and
the District of Columbia.
Students 'Self-Satisfied'

JAY STICKMEN HUMBLE

Cast For ‘The Torchbearers,'
4Stormers' Production, Chosen
The Jays opened the half with
Begin With Confidence

extreme confidence. The team maneuvered down the field in a smooth
style and, after several careless
shots, Jack Trumbull broke the ice
with a clean tally.
The Cavaliers now seemed determined to stop any further Jay
scores but Hopkins' brilliant offense continued to wend its way
down to the Virginia goal with
ease.
On Shooting Spree

The second half found the Black
and Blue on a shooting spree.
Within a few ,minutes the score
was doubled. At this moment,
Coach Van Orman began to inject
practically every substitute on the
team.
This game also marked the debut
of Jack Gilbert, Fritz Studes' understudy at goal. However, since
most of the game was fought in
Virginia territory, very little comment can be made on the new
goalies' play.
Subsitutions Were Frequent

At times substitutions became so
frequent that the teams had to be
lined up in order to allow each
player to know his opponent.
However, the substitutes again
displayed their versatility by con(Continued on page 4, column 3)

students here, Dr. E. W. Berry,
dean of the College of Arts and
Sciences, has arranged a definite
schedule which has been published
in the new edition of the catalog
for the college, released Friday afternoon.
'Cramped' Schedule Relieved

Classes in the college will be held
from 8:30 a. m. to 3:20 p. m., with
the lunch hour from 12:30 p. m. to
1 :30 p. in. This adds an additional
half hour for the lunch. More
classes than usual, also, will be
held on Saturday. This has been
worked out in order to relieve
what has been termed the "cramped" condition of the schedule.
It was indicated at Homewood
that the filling out of the schedules will be done more easily and
with greater rapidity and efficiency.
Four Hours for French

The French reading course for
students who do not intend to continue further in the study of the
language is to be designated by 1 C,
and not 01 C as before. Four
hours are to be allotted to this new
1 C course, instead of the usual
three.
Next term the survey- course in
mathematics, instructed by Dr. A.
Cohen, which was abandoned this
college year because of a lack of
requests to take the new course,
will be given.
New Courses In History

In the department of history, a
new course, national and liberal
movements in nineteenth century
Europe, will be given by Dr. Kent
R. Greenfield. Dr. S. M. Painter,
a new associate in history, will
teach a course in the history of
England. Foreign relations of the
United States will be a new course
given by Dr. W. S. Holt.
Advanced public speaking is
scheduled for next year.

EDITORIAL DEPARTMENT

wholly self-supporting. This means that
they must add several working hours
to the study hours. On top of this one
puts an extra-curricular activity or two
and a date a week, and the result is
four or five hours for sleep per dium.
"Taking all this into consideration
seems to show a very different college
than the popular conception. An
education is not an easy thing for most
people to come by. The four years of
'easy life' are very busy ones, and if
the life in the great big bad world becomes as hard, the mortality rate is due
for a large jump."
We agree heartily with the above
view and feel that the many people
who now hold the erroneous view that
college is only a four year loaf, would
do well to examine the facts of the
case a little more closely and discover
their mistake.

The Four Year Loaf
The following editorial appeared in
a recent issue of the California Daily
Bruin:
"The majority of the general public
seems to have the idea, garnered in
most cases from the various college
movies and humor magazines, that the
four years of college are four years of
easy life, undertaken to put off going
to work as long as possible.
"Anyone who has attended college
realizes that the 'four year loaf' is not
such a bed of roses as outsiders would
suspect. Many a graduating senior
breathes a sigh of relief when the
sheepskin is handed to him and he
realizes that his days of labor are over;
all he will have to do now is work
eight hours a day.
"Not only must the student spend
many hours a day on his studying, but

Very Brief Mention
By H. L. F,
Since Mr. Schaal has requested
me by embassy to comment on the
eight-year statistical survey on
liberalism appearing elsewhere in
the NEWS-LETTER today, I feel
constrained to accommodate him. I
could, of course, point out that the
observations that Mr. Schaal has
characterized as "scientific" were

made from such ponderous evidence as may be derived from a
study of nine out of the several
thousands of colleges in the United
States. But I don't think I will.
The fact that it took Mr. Schaal
eight years to discover that the
Johns Hopkins is not a liberal college is significant in itself.
